titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 4. Sworn at the Capitol— symbols

list.item: Mrs De Wint, Mrs. Frye, Mrs W. S. Smith
Ball and Supper— Home at 11.— Rain

div.p: 5. VII. Genl. Brown— Adjutt. Genls. Office— Coll. R. Jones.
James Barbour
S. L. Southard
D. Brent symbols C. Cutts with Treaties and appointments
N. Macon and T. W. Cobb.
Visits of gratulation and T.T.L many.
James Lloyd and N. Macon, Comee. of Senate to notify they were in Session— Answer.
Sent D. Brent with nominations.
Sent for J. R. Poinsett— Offered him the Mission to Mexico. will answer to-morrow— Richard. Gabriel— for a book.
Walk— met Calhoun. Blunt.
Eve at the Capitol— Owen’s Lecture failed— Call on R. King.
Crowninshield T.T.L.
6. VII— Sent for A. H. Everett.
Heard Little— Deuteronomy 16.20— Post— Proverbs 23.26.
Cushman. T. Finlay— D. P. Cook.
Call on Clay who is unwell. Storrs with him— Long Conversation— Genl. Jackson’s Letter to S. Swartwout.
T. Scott of Ohio, John Gray, and dined with us—
Dearborn, Wingate, Edward Ingersoll here— Poinsett accepts.
Johnson Hellen went to Rockville.
7. VII. Anderson— Comptroller here.
S. L. Southard— Acting Secy Treasury.
Land Patents signed 251.
Military Warrants blank—12.
D. Brent— Sent him with nominations to Senate.
Lanman excluded from his Seat.
W. Findlay and Wever.— Levi S. Burr. Jery. Robinson—
Numerous Letters— Applications and Recommendations.
G. Sullivan— Walk with him— He and E. Cruft dined with us.
Eve at Owen’s Lecture— Long— Southard objected to as acting Secy Treasy—by Anderson the Comptroller.
Cruft took leave— Power to G. W. A— 11400 State. Bank. 1000. per annum to George.
8. V:45.— George, Charles and Mrs De Wint, off in the Stage.
G. Graham— Receiver’s Office at Cincinnati—for nomination
Marks’s S.U.S.
Ross—of Newburgh—for a minor office abroad.
9. VI.— Upper chamber.
11. VI:30.Elgar— Levelling grounds.
VI:30 12. Teller place— Custom House KY
13. V:45— Heard Little— Philippians 1.11.

list.head:
Meeting on Como Porter’s affairs
Court of Enquiry— Tingey. Jones, Morris

div.p: 15. V:45.G. Graham— Surveyor’s Office Mississippi

list.item: Webster— symbols R. King. Mason and Hopkinson.
R. Cutts— Letter from E. Shapley about M. L. Hill
Jos. Story— Commission for J. T. Mansfield Pernambuco
Carbery— Letter from Kent and Neale for place
Dashiell— to be restored as a Cadet.
Southard— Court of enquiry for Porter
Mrs Meigs— Do for her Sons—
H. Wheaton— Letter from Latham A. Burrows— N.Y. Senate
symbolsAt P.U.S. and at C. B. King’s— Southard at eve 200

div.p: 16. VI.30.Joseph Dixon— A Seaman for place

list.item: Clay— Everett’s Accounts— State Dept. Expenditures

div.p: 17. V.45.G. Graham— Reserve of Land in Florida—

list.item: Williams of N. Jersey— Place in Marine Corps, or elsewhere.
T. Randall— His Accounts. Naples— Com: Porter—
Jennings— Jonn. Indiana Bank arrangemt.J. B. Thomas
Brown Genl. Army affairs— Scott and Gaines— Bissell—
W. G. D. Worthington— for place
J. L. Sullivan— War Department order. His daughter.
Strobel— Consul at Bordeaux. for a place at home.
Reynolds. W— House for Archives at St. Augustine.
Clay— Draft of Instructions to Poinsett.
G. cannon— Place, Collector of Nantucket
S. L. Southard— Revenue Cutter’s— S.C. Judgmt Penalties.
A. H. Everett. going to Boston.

div.p: 18. V:45.James Barbour— Arkansas— Georgia— Creeks and Cherokees— J. L. Sullivan resigns—accepted

list.item: D. Brent. Izzard’s Commission. Instructions to Hughes
W. Lee. Enquiries, Mrs A’s health. Offers of service—
Levi S. Burr— for place— and W. Smith for Jus. Pac.
J. Bailey— for Marston— Wheaton. Vail— Eugene.
Wheaton H. t.t.l. going with Webster—
Menard— Coll.— going, to see N. Pope
Baker— Daniel— with Letter from Eph. Gilman

div.p: 19 V—45. S. L. Southard— Baltimore Ship-building &c

list.item: Hugh Maguire— Appointment as Jus. Pac:
G. S. Bourne— Engaged with Mr Owen of Lanark at Harmony.
W. D. Lewis—with speeches of C. J. and Jos. R. Ingersoll

list.head:
Meeting— Instructions to Poinsett. Cuba.
Non Colonization— fugitive Slaves— Indians to be pardoned— Baltimore Ship-building.

list.item: Mrs W. S. Smith to dine with us— Mrs A. eve abroad
A. H. Everett— to take leave— Going to morrow.

div.p: 20. VI. Owen of Lanark— Goes on Tuesday for Harmony

list.item: G. Hay— Has written an Essay on the Spirit of party.
W. D. Lewis dined with us— W. Lee in the Evening.

div.p: 21. VI. Dr. J. Thomas— Place. Letters from Graham & M’Pherson

list.item: Hammond of N.Y— Sale of Fortifications to U.S.
Slade— Mistake in nomination of T. H Jervey.
W. S. Smith with C. Varlé, an Engineer.
Clay.— Address to his late Constituents.
Rebello— To congratulate—has been very ill.
Poinsett— Has Instructions— Will go next week
P.U.S— Goes for Loudoun, day after to-morrow
T. Ringgold— S.C. adjourned this Evening.
Pardon to Mad Buffaloe and Little. Eagle Osages

div.p: 22. V:45.S. L. Southard— Despatches from I. Hull

list.item: Court martial on Carter, Mull and Van Dyke.
D. Brent— Letter from T. Randall— Meditn. Passports
Bulfinch. C.— Clerkship— for his Son C. Recommendations
Major Lehmanowsky— for a Clerkship— La Fayette’s recomn
Ch: Varlé—for employment as civil engineer— Delaware Canal
James S. Scott. for place— Letter from D. P. Cook.
J. E. Calhoun— Expedn. to Pacific Ocean—

list.head: Invitation to a dinner with Mrs Monroe

list.item: Judge Thompson— t.t.l. going fort New-York to-morrow.
J. Barbour Secy. War— Answer to Forsyth— Creeks and Cherokees.
Brown to be appointed a Cadet. a promise
Evening with Mrs A. at Mr Frye’s— Whist.

div.p: 23. VI. Williams again for the place in Pension Office.

Mr Monroe & family departed for Loudoun— Call at the President’s house— Escort, to the Bridge— Major Andrews troop of horse— Took leave of Mr Monroe— John & Burton with me— Calhoun, Barbour, Southard, Wirt, Genl. Brown, Coll. Jones &c—there. Home
Elgar— of the House— Mrs Adams went over it. Key delivered to me— Sent Antoine to receive the effects compared with the inventory.
H. Clay— Instructions to C. Hughes— Clay’s Address to his Constituents.
Moncure Robinson. with Letter form Govr Pleasants.
M. S. C. Clarke, with Letter from David Fullerton, for place.
J. M’Lean P.M. General— Postmaster at New-York.— Kent, employment of H. Lee, in the Post-Office.
S. L. Southard— Order for Advances to Officers abroad—
24. V:45.Gilbert C. Russell— Charges agt.Captn. de Russy—

list.item: Chace of Coln. College for Timothy Savage, Survr. Middletown—
D. Brent— concerning the nominations—and errors
L. Smith— Claims of G. and F. Eichelberger.
J. Bailey— Richmond’s Letter. Appointments & discontent.
Stewart— agt.Genl. Browns order to remove troops from Mackinaw
H. Clay— His Address— Remarks— T. Randall’s claim. Pedersen.
S. L. Southard— Draft of Letter to I. Hull— rectified.
He is going to-morrow for Mrs Southard—

div.p: 25. V:30.D. Brent— Letter from Govr C. P. Van Ness, fugitives from Canada.
26. VI. Captain Angus— Reinstatement— Promise of Mr Monroe.

list.item: D. Brent— A pardon for Burt— Also N. Mead. Shapley’s opinion
James Barbour— Choctaw Indian Schools— Also Creeks.
Cumberland road contn. Private property Ruggles
H. Clay— Brown’s complaint agt. Patent Office—
Instructions for Ministers— Boundary of Maine—
Purchase of Province of New Brunswick.
Brazil— Suppression of Slave trade. New views of.
Jas. A. Campbell— Wants passage to Mexico—in the Constellation—
Met G. Sullivan— Claim— and Clay for Campbell

div.p: 27. VI: At St. John’s Church. Heard Allen— Amos 6.1.

list.item: A visitor—name unknown from Arkansas Terry.

div.p: 28. VI. T. Watkins— Cut glass— and M’Culloh—

list.item: Dr. Shaw— About De W. Clinton— J. C. Calhoun, M’Lean and the Post-Office. Mower and Judge Spencer— much information concerning all— Confidences of Clinton, Spencer and Calhoun
New-York Law for choosing Electors by Districts— its importance.
H. Clay— Draft of Letter to H. U. Addington— Maine boundary.
Interruption of fishermen. Armed vessel— Fort or garrison.
J. H. Pleasants to go as bearer of despatches— His father may come to the Senate
Shriver, Genl. Bernard, Captain Poussin, and two other Assistants— T.t.L— going to-morrow for New-Orleans—
At the President’s house—with Elgar; examining the furniture.
Met F. Key, who lent me a pamphlet— Fallenberg and Hofwyl—
R. B. Lee to recommend C. C. Coote as Justice of Peace— Letters—
Sessford and with a Museum Subscription.
G. Sullivan— About Calhoun— Clay’s publication this day.
J. R. Poinsett— To go on Wednesday. Mexican Boundary.

div.p: 29. VI. G. Graham— Appointment of Surveyor in Louisiana under Davis— Turner recommended by Matthews. Approval of Katchell’s Letter. Reservation— of Salina, in Illinois.

list.item: W. Brown— Salary of Secy of State, from 3. to 6. March— Whether to D. Brent—or to the surplus fund?
G. Sullivan— About the Claim. To speak to Hagner—
A. Scott, with a recommendatory Letter from Mr Monroe.
H. Clay— Instruction to Brown about the Coronation.
Letters from J. Tyler— and H. Storrs—of Clinton
Forsyth with him yesterday— friendly professions.
At the President’s House—finished examination of furniture with Elgar.
Swan of Alexandria—dinner 13. April at 4. O Clock
J. R. Poinsett. Dr Shaw and G. Sullivan dined with us

div.p: 30. VI Du Bothmann father and Son, Germans from Baltimore

list.item: Captain Angus, with a Letter from Mr Monroe.
B. Bayly— for Clerkship vacant in 3d. Auditor’s Office.
Dr. Shaw— Long talk about Clinton, Calhoun, Sanford, Genl Brown &c
J. C. Calhoun— T.t.l—going to-morrow for S. Carolina
J. R. Poinsett— with E. Tayloe— Going this day, for Mexico
J. Bailey. T.t.l. going to morrow, for Dorchester.
James Barbour—Letter to Ruggles— Contn. of Cumberland road.
Complaint of G. C. Russell agt.De Rossy—
Politics of Virginia— Barbour going to-morrow—
Burton left us— Returning to Richmond. Va.
Met John Mason jr— Going for Mexico—to the Steam-boat.

div.p: 31. V:45.Collins & Taylor— For place— Messenger &c—

list.item: D. Brent— Enquiry about Commissions. Session Laws
H. Clay— Case of the Pearl. Tuyll’s proposals 10 or 1200.
G. C. Russell— Complaint agt.P. Hagner.
Boyden.— Invention for loading a musket.
T. Randall— Correspondence with Navy Dept. abt.Com: Porter.
Walk and looked in to the House, with John.
Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us.

div.p: Day— Rise at 6. Read an hour— Write irregularly till nine— Letters, or past diary— Breakfast. an hour. Visitors, and interrupted reading till four— Walk an hour and a half— Read till dinner at six— From two to three hours in the Evening employed in signing Blank Land-grants, Sea-Letters, Mediterranean Passports, and Patents— The business with the Heads of Departments is at various times, as they come, between breakfast and dinner, as yet with out method or order— Some preparations have been made for removing, which cannot yet for several days be completed—
